A polynomial time algorithm to approximate the mixed volume within a simply exponential factor

Leonid Gurvits gurvits@lanl.gov. Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM.

We prove the mixed volume analogues of the Van der Waerden and Schrijver-Valiant conjectures on the permanent. These results, interesting on their own, allow us to justify the abovementioned approximation by a convex minimization, which is solved using the ellipsoid method and a randomized poly-time time algorithm for the approximation of the volume of a convex set.

The problem of computing the mixed volume of convex bodies is also important for combinatorics and algebraic geometry [7]. For instance, the number of toric solutions to a system of n𝑛nitalic_n polynomial equations on 𝐂nsuperscript𝐂𝑛{{\bf C}}^{n}bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is upper bounded by—and for a generic system, equal to—the mixed volume of the Newton polytopes of the the corresponding polynomials. This remarkable result, called the BKK Theorem, is covered, for instance, in [25] and [5]).

1.1 Previous Work

The BKK Theorem created an “industry” of computing (exactly) the mixed volume of integer polytopes and its various generalizations; most algorithms in the area are of exponential runing time ([18],[9], [11] and many more). Most researchers in the “industry” don’t bother to formally write down the complexity, rather they describe the actual amount of the computer time. Although there was a substantial algorithmic activity on the mixed volume of polytopes prior to [7], the paper [7] was the first, to our knowledge, systematic complexity-theoretic study in the area. It followed naturally upon the famous FPRAS algorithms [6] for volumes of convex bodies, solved several natural problems and posed many important hard questions. The existence of FPRAS for the mixed volume even for polytopes or ellipsoids is still an open problem.

Efficient polynomial-time probabilistic algorithms that approximate the mixed volume extremely tightly (within a (1+ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ) factor) were developed for some classes of well-presented convex bodies [7]. The algorithms in [7] are based on the multivariate polynomial interpolation and work if and only if the number k𝑘kitalic_k of distinct convex sets in the tuple 𝐊𝐊{\bf K}bold_K is “small”, i.e. k=O⁢(log⁡(n))𝑘𝑂𝑛k=O(\log(n))italic_k = italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_n ) ).
The first efficient probabilistic algorithm that provides a nO⁢(n)superscript𝑛𝑂𝑛n^{O(n)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-factor approximation for arbitrary well-presented proper convex bodies was obtained by Barvinok [2]. Barvinok’s algorithms start by replacing convex bodies with ellipsoids. This first step already gives nO⁢(n)superscript𝑛𝑂𝑛n^{O(n)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-factor in the worst case. After that the mixed volume of ellipsoids is approximated with a simply exponential factor cnsuperscript𝑐𝑛c^{n}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by two randomized algorithms; one of those deals with approximation of the mixed discriminant.

The question of existence of an efficient deterministic algorithm for approximating the mixed volume of arbitrary well-presented proper convex bodies with an error depending only on the dimension was posed in [7]. The authors quote a lower bound (Bárány and Füredi bound) [1] of (Ω⁢(nlog⁡n))n2superscriptΩ𝑛𝑛𝑛2\left(\Omega\left(\frac{n}{\log n}\right)\right)^{\frac{n}{2}}( roman_Ω ( divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the approximation factor of such an algorithm. (Notice that Barvinok’s randomized algorithm [2] does not beat the Bárány and Füredi bound.)

Deterministic polynomial-time algorithms that approximate the mixed volume with a factor of nO⁢(n)superscript𝑛𝑂𝑛n^{O(n)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT were given, for a fixed number of distinct proper convex bodies in 𝐊=(K1,…,Kn)𝐊subscript𝐾1…subscript𝐾𝑛{\bf K}=(K_{1},\ldots,K_{n})bold_K = ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), in [2], [7]. Finally, a deterministic polynomial-time algorithm that approximates the mixed volume with a factor of nO⁢(n)superscript𝑛𝑂𝑛n^{O(n)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the general case of well-presented compact convex sets was given in [13],[14]. The approximation of the mixed discriminant has also been relaxed to a convex optimization problem (geometric programming). In order to prove the accuracy of the convex relaxation, the author proved in [15] the mixed discriminant analogue of the Van der Waerden conjecture on permanents of doubly stochastic matrices [21], which was posed by R. V. Bapat in [3].

To summarize, the interpolational approach from [7] is limited by the restriction that the number of distinct convex sets is O⁢(log⁡(n))𝑂𝑛O(\log(n))italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_n ) ); previous approaches [2], [13], [14] can’t give the simply exponential approximation factor cnsuperscript𝑐𝑛c^{n}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT because of the initial approximation of convex sets by ellipsoids.

1.2 Our Approach

2.3 Comparison with previous results

The inequality (3) is an analogue of the famous Van der Waerden conjecture [21], proved in [10] and [8], on the permanent of doubly-stochastic matrices. Indeed, consider the “boxes” Ki={(x1,…,xn):0≤xj≤A⁢(i,j),1≤j≤n}subscript𝐾𝑖conditional-setsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛formulae-sequence0subscript𝑥𝑗𝐴𝑖𝑗1𝑗𝑛K_{i}=\{(x_{1},...,x_{n}):0\leq x_{j}\leq A(i,j),1\leq j\leq n\}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : 0 ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_A ( italic_i , italic_j ) , 1 ≤ italic_j ≤ italic_n }. Then the mixed volume is equal to the permanent,

V⁢(𝐊)=V⁢(K1,…,Kn)=P⁢e⁢r⁢m⁢(A),𝑉𝐊𝑉subscript𝐾1…subscript𝐾𝑛𝑃𝑒𝑟𝑚𝐴V({\bf K})=V(K_{1},\ldots,K_{n})=Perm(A),italic_V ( bold_K ) = italic_V ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_P italic_e italic_r italic_m ( italic_A ) ,

and if the n×n𝑛𝑛n\times nitalic_n × italic_n matrix A𝐴Aitalic_A is doubly-stochastic then C⁢a⁢p⁢(V𝐊)=1𝐶𝑎𝑝subscript𝑉𝐊1Cap(V_{{\bf K}})=1italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1.

Though this mixed volume representation of the permanent has been known since the publication of [8] if not earlier, the author is not aware of any attempts prior to the present paper to generalize the Van der Waerden conjecture to the mixed volume. We think that our version, stated in terms of the capacity, is most natural and useful.

The inequality (10) is an analogue of Schrijver’s lower bound [27], [17] on the number of perfect matchings in k𝑘kitalic_k-regular bipartite graphs: affine dimensions play role of the degrees of vertices.

The reader familiar with [17] can recognize the similarity between inequalities (9), (3), (10) and the corresponding inequalities in [17], proved for H-Stable polynomials. The method of proof in the present paper is also similar to the one in [17] (in spite of the fact that not all Minkowski polynomials V𝐊subscript𝑉𝐊V_{{\bf K}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are H-Stable). But we get worse constants: for instance, if k=2𝑘2k=2italic_k = 2, in the notation of (10), then in the H-Stable case we get the factor 2−n+1superscript2𝑛12^{-n+1}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT instead of the 12⁢(1+2)2−n12superscript122𝑛\frac{1}{2}(1+\sqrt{2})^{2-n}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained in this paper. Whether the latter factor is asymptotically sharp is an open problem.

2.4 The idea of our proof

Our proof of Bapat’s conjecture in [15], i.e. of Van der Waerden conjecture for the mixed discriminant, is an adaptation of Egorychev’s proof in [8]. In contrast, the proofs in [17] and in the present paper have practically nothing in common either with Egorychev’s proof or with Falikman’s proof in [10].

  1. 1.

    How do we prove the lower bounds?
    We follow the general approach by the present author, introduced in [17].
    We associate with the Minkowski polynomial V𝐊subscript𝑉𝐊V_{{\bf K}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a sequence of polynomials:

    qn=V𝐊,qi⁢(x1,…,xi)=∂n−i∂xi+1⁢…⁢∂xn⁢qn⁢(x1,…,xi,0,…,0),1≤i≤n−1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑉𝐊formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑖0…01𝑖𝑛1q_{n}=V_{{\bf K}},q_{i}(x_{1},...,x_{i})=\frac{\partial^{n-i}}{\partial x_{i+1}...\partial x_{n}}q_{n}(x_{1},...,x_{i},0,...,0),1\leq i\leq n-1.italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG ∂ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT … ∂ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 , … , 0 ) , 1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_n - 1 .

    Note that q1⁢(x)=V⁢(K1,…,Kn)⁢xsubscript𝑞1𝑥𝑉subscript𝐾1…subscript𝐾𝑛𝑥q_{1}(x)=V(K_{1},\ldots,K_{n})xitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_V ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_x. Everything follows from the next inequality

    C⁢a⁢p⁢(qi)≥λ⁢(i+1,min⁡(i+1,a⁢f⁢f⁢(i+1)))⁢C⁢a⁢p⁢(qi+1),1≤i≤n−1.formulae-sequence𝐶𝑎𝑝subscript𝑞𝑖𝜆𝑖1𝑖1𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖1𝐶𝑎𝑝subscript𝑞𝑖11𝑖𝑛1Cap(q_{i})\geq\lambda\left(i+1,\min(i+1,aff(i+1))\right)Cap(q_{i+1}),1\leq i\leq n-1.italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥ italic_λ ( italic_i + 1 , roman_min ( italic_i + 1 , italic_a italic_f italic_f ( italic_i + 1 ) ) ) italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_n - 1 .

    Not surprisingly, we do use the (still hard to prove) Alexandrov-Fenchel inequalities to prove this crucial inequality. (In contrast, the H-Stable case in [17] required just the elementary AG inequality).

  2. 2.

    How do we prove the uniqueness?

    The uniqueness proofs in [8] and [15] are critically based on the known characterization of the equality cases in the Alexandrov inequalities for the mixed discriminant. In the case of the Alexandrov-Fenchel inequalities for the mixed volume such a characterization is not known. Luckily, the method of our proof of the lower bound (3) allows us to use the well known characterization of equality in the (much simpler) Brunn-Minkowski inequality. The uniqueness proof in the present paper is very similar to the uniqueness proof in [17]. The fundamental tool in [17] was Gårding’s famous (and not hard to prove) result on the convexity of the hyperbolic cone.

3 Convex Optimization Relaxation of the Mixed Volume

Inequalities (9, 3, 10) justify the following strategy for approximation of the mixed volume V⁢(K1,…,Kn)𝑉subscript𝐾1…subscript𝐾𝑛V(K_{1},\ldots,K_{n})italic_V ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) within a simply exponential multiplicative factor: solve the convex optimization problem (2) with an additive O⁢(1)𝑂1O(1)italic_O ( 1 ) error. We follow here the approach from [13, 14] which dealt with the following problem:

log⁡(C⁢a⁢p⁢(D⁢e⁢t𝐀))=infy1+…+yn=0log⁡(det(∑1≤i≤neyi⁢Ai)):Ai⪰0.:𝐶𝑎𝑝𝐷𝑒subscript𝑡𝐀subscriptinfimumsubscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑛0subscript1𝑖𝑛superscript𝑒subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝐴𝑖0\log(Cap(Det_{{\bf A}}))=\inf_{y_{1}+...+y_{n}=0}\log\left(\det(\sum_{1\leq i\leq n}e^{y_{i}}A_{i})\right):A_{i}\succeq 0.roman_log ( italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_D italic_e italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + … + italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( roman_det ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) : italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⪰ 0 . The main difference between the two problems is that the value and the gradient of determinantal polynomials can be exactly evaluated in deterministic polynomial time. The case of the Minkowski polynomials V𝐊subscript𝑉𝐊V_{{\bf K}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT requires some extra care. Yet, this is done using standard and well known tools. This section of the paper is fairly routine and can be easily reproduced by any convex optimization professional.

We now give an overview of the main points:

3.1 A brief overview

  1. 1.

    Representations of convex sets and a priori ball for the convex relaxation: we deal in this paper with two types of representations. 3.5 Putting things together

4 Open Problems

  1. 1.

    Prove that for “random” convex sets V⁢(K1,…,Kn)C⁢a⁢p⁢(V𝐊)≤n!nn⁢O⁢(1)𝑉subscript𝐾1…subscript𝐾𝑛𝐶𝑎𝑝subscript𝑉𝐊𝑛superscript𝑛𝑛𝑂1\frac{V(K_{1},\ldots,K_{n})}{Cap(V_{{\bf K}})}\leq\frac{n!}{n^{n}}O(1)divide start_ARG italic_V ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG italic_n ! end_ARG start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_O ( 1 ) with high probability. This is true for the permanents of random matrices with nonnegative entries.

  2. 2.

    The most important question is whether or not there exists a FPRAS algorithm for the mixed volume (or for the mixed discriminant). We conjecture that the answer is negative.

  3. 3.

    Another important open problem is whether or not our mixed volume generalization (10) of Schrijver’s lower bound on the number of perfect matchings in regular bipartite graphs [27], [29], [17] is asymptotically sharp.

A.3 Proof of Theorem (2.4)
